item.title: Let's Look at some Python!
item.description: No, not the snake!! In case that was triggering here is a picture of my dogs dressed like lions on Halloween. Time to do some actual coding… In R library(reticulate) thats <- "I don't" And in python! me="like snakes!" print(r.thats,me) ## I don't like snakes! Thanks for reading my post! You just found out some super secretive information about me! Enjoy :)

item.title: Project 1: Exploratory Data Analysis
item.description: Grace Buchen, gb23396 Data Wrangling and Data Exploration Finding data: library(AER) data("USSeatBelts") library(readr) Consumption_Alcohol <- read_csv("Consumption_Alcohol.csv", col_types = cols(Beer = col_number(), Wine = col_number(), Spirits = col_number(), `All beverages` = col_number())) library(tidyverse) library(dplyr) When starting this project, I wanted to choose a topic that was important to me. In exploring the datasets in R, I found the USSeatBelts dataset. This dataset looks at traffic fatalities and seat belt usage for the years 1983–1997 for states in the U.

item.title: Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: Grace Buchen, gb23396 Modeling Finding data: library(AER) data("NMES1988") library(tidyverse) library(dplyr) medical <- NMES1988 %>% slice(1:2000) Due to the size of the original dataset, I decided to cut down the number of observations from 4406 to 2000 in order to more easily explore the data. For this project, I chose to use the NMES1988 dataset as it deals with health data for individuals 66 years and older which is a topic that is very interesting to me as I want to work in health care.

item.title: Projects
item.description: Check out some of my coding projects below: Wrangling & Exploratory Data Analysis Modeling, Inference, Prediction --
